courses.subject: GENA
courses.title: College Biweekly Assembly
courses.description: The College organizes regular Bi-weekly Assemblies to broaden the understanding of students on university life, social issues, world cultures and arts through series of talks. Student Colloquia and public lectures are also organized to provide interactive platforms for exchange of ideas and views with eminent speakers, with an aim to raise the awareness of students towards different contemporary issues in the community and the world.
courses.enrollment_requirement: New Asia College Assembly
courses.learning_outcomes:
1) Students will be able to gain an understanding on university life, social issues, world cultures and arts.

2) Through this common learning experience the students will build a sense of belonging to the College.
courses.course_syllabus: The College invites speakers from various professions to deliver the talk.
courses.feedback_evaluation: Questionnaires.
courses.recommended_readings: Nil

courses.subject: GENA
courses.title: Aspects of General Education
courses.description: The basic objective of the course is to broaden the horizon of first year students of New Asia College. Adopting an ecological model, topics related to the developmental contexts of university students, including cultural system, societal system, school system and personal system are introduced in the course. Students taking this course will be able to acquire a basic understanding of the Chinese culture, Hong Kong society, university life, and their own development. In addition, students are encouraged to develop critical views on the related issues in these areas.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For New Asia College year 1 students only
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of the course, students will be able to:

1) describe basic knowledge in various cultures, and the College spirit.

2) interpret social issues in Hong Kong from different perspectives.

3) adapt to university life and appreciate essential characteristics of university learning.

4) develop inter-cultural sensitivity and appreciate different cultures and social issues in a global context.

5) recognize the common concerns of contemporary physical and social environment.

6) strengthen their motivation for intellectual learning.
courses.course_syllabus:
Chinese Culture

(1) The Ideal and Spirit of New Asia College

(2) Chinese History

Hong Kong Society

(3) Media and Hong Kong Culture

(4) Sustainable Development

University Education

(5) Library and Information Science

(6) Architecture

(7) Art Appreciation

(8) Philosophy

Personal Development

(9) Mental Health of University Students

(10) Personal Ethics

(11) Leadership Skills

(12) Holistic Development for University Students

The topics will be confirmed on yearly basis, and will fall into the specific knowledge areas mentioned.

courses.subject: GENA
courses.title: Service Learning - Bringing Chinese Culture into Local Community
courses.description:
Promoting Chinese history and culture is one of the core missions of New Asia College. “Service Learning – Bringing Chinese Culture into Local Community” encourages students to participate in activities about Chinese culture and/or cultural conservation projects in local community through observation, recording, promotion and transmission. This course aims to enhance students’ understanding of the meanings and values of traditional Chinese cultural heritages (both tangible and intangible) and the spirit they inherit in a modern and cosmopolitan city. The course also aims to integrate service and learning experiences through community service activities. It seeks to cultivate students’ leadership skills and foster their self-awareness and empathy towards others and the community. In addition, the programme also emphasizes reflection on the quality of service leadership with particular focus on intrapersonal and interpersonal competencies.

There will be different sessions under this course that focus on various aspects of Chinese culture, for example, moral values, arts, customs and festivals, etc. Through the delivery of service, the students will be able to share with the members of local community the experience of appreciating Chinese culture and its values.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
1. Not for students who have taken GENA1115, 1116, 1117, 2352 or ELTU2008.
2. For New Asia College year 1 students only.
courses.course_syllabus:
This course consists of three parts – i) lectures, ii) fieldwork and on-site service, and iii) presentation and report.

Week 1 - 4

A series of 4 lectures on basic concepts of service learning, theories of heritage preservation, fieldwork methods, and various Chinese cultural heritage in Hong Kong and its current situation.

Week 5 - 12

Students will then be divided into groups, with 4 to 6 students in each group. Each group is required to select a Chinese cultural heritage item (i.e. custom, festival, handicraft, performing arts, temple, monastery, ancestral hell etc.), OR a local Chinese community (i.e. village, market etc.) to carry out a minimum of 13 hours of fieldwork and on-site service. The aim of fieldwork and on-site service is to record or promote the selected Chinese cultural heritage. There are various forms of service such as local tour, interview, design of promotional materials, storytelling, role-play, games, etc, subject to the approval of the course instructor.

The course instructor is expected to conduct at least one session of on-site supervision for each group in order to assess students’ performance and commitment while peer-evaluation is also implemented.

Week 13

Each group will present their projects in the last meeting, followed by a self-reflection session. A group report is also required to submit by the end of the course.

courses.subject: GENA
courses.title: Service Learning – Make a Difference to Our Community

meetings.location: Lee Shau Kee Archi Bldg G02
Lee Shau Kee Archi Bldg G02
Lee Shau Kee Archi Bldg G02
Lee Shau Kee Archi Bldg G02

courses.description:
“Service Learning – Make a Difference to Our Community” aims to enable students to use sustainable methods to help local community or socially disadvantaged groups. In collaborating with different NGOs and university departments or research units, students will be introduced to key concepts and theories of sustainable development and explore how to apply them to proposing solutions to the needs and difficulties faced by disadvantaged groups. The course also aims to integrate service and learning experiences through community service activities. It seeks to cultivate students’ leadership skills and foster their self-awareness and empathy towards others and the community. In addition, the program also emphasizes reflection on the quality of service leadership with particular focus on intrapersonal and interpersonal competencies.

There will be different sessions under the course that focus on various aspects of sustainable development, for example, poverty, clean energy, marine pollution, etc. Through the service-learning activities, students and community members are expected to foster their cohesiveness and concerns about the local community.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
1. Not for students who have taken GENA1114, 1116, 1117, 2352 or ELTU2008.
2. For New Asia College year 1 students only.
courses.course_attributes:
SDG-GE #1 No Poverty
SDG-GE #7 Affordable and Clean Energy
SDG-GE #14 Life Below Water
Service Learning Course
courses.course_syllabus:
This course consists of three parts – i) lectures, ii) on-site visit and service, and iii) presentation and report.

Week 1 - 4

Basic concepts of service learning, sustainability, and social welfare in Hong Kong will be addressed in a series of four lectures.

Week 5 - 12

Students will then be divided into groups of 4 to 6 persons to carry out the community engagement programme. Each group is required to choose one social disadvantaged group, visit them and identify their needs and difficulties. After the visit, students should propose and initiate a solution to the chosen group with the application of sustainable methods. The total hour of on-site visit and service is no less than 13 hours.

The course instructor is expected to conduct at least one session of on-site supervision for each group in order to assess students’ performance and commitment while peer-evaluation is also implemented.

Week 13

Each group will present their learning outcomes in the last meeting, followed by a self-reflection session. A group report is also required to submit by the end of the course.

courses.subject: GENA
courses.title: Service Learning – Creating a Better World through Diversity and Inclusion
courses.description:
“Service Learning – Creating a Better World through Diversity and Inclusion” aims to promote diversity and inclusion to the community. The course will create opportunities for students to get in touch with vulnerable groups or minority members in the city. By engaging in a variety of projects or activities such as in-depth visits and interviews, students are expected to understand the environment and difficulties their target groups have been facing. The course consists of lectures, service learning experiences, and self-reflection sessions. Key concepts such as openness, civility, and inclusivity will be discussed in class, while a core principle that no individual and group should be discriminated against based on race, ethnicity, geographic provenance, nationality, gender, sexual orientation, age, religion, language, ability/disability, or socioeconomic status will be stressed as these values and principles are embraced by the University and are essential to social cohesion. The course also aims to integrate service and learning experiences through community service activities. It seeks to cultivate students’ leadership skills and foster their self-awareness and empathy towards others and the community. In addition, the course also emphasizes reflection on the quality of leadership that demonstrates while providing service, with the particular focus on intrapersonal and interpersonal competencies.

There will be different sessions under this course that focus on various aspects and subjects under the general theme diversity and inclusion, for example, multicultural groups, Special Educational Needs (SEN), gender equality, etc. Through the delivery of service, the students will be equipped with skills and a positive attitude to tackle social issues through collaborating with different NGO partners, and ultimately, be able to apply their knowledge and skills to real-world settings in meaningful and impactful ways.

Diversity and inclusion are crucial principles of achieving the SDG goals of “Gender Equality” and “Reducing Inequality”. By respecting different cultures and minimizing stereotypes and prejudices, it will promote an atmosphere conducive to “Good Health and Well-being” of our society, with particular concern of mental health.

Week 5 - 12

Students will then be divided into groups, with 4 to 6 students in each group. Each group is required to select a minority group (i.e. ethnic minority, disadvantage groups, gender, SEN etc.) to carry out a minimum of 13 hours of fieldwork and on-site service. The aim of fieldwork and on-site service is to record or promote diversity and inclusion to the community. There are various forms of service such as local tour, interview, design of promotional materials, storytelling, role-play, games, etc, subject to the approval of the course instructor.

The course instructor is expected to conduct at least one session of on-site supervision for each group in order to assess students’ performance and commitment while peer-evaluation is also implemented.

Week 13

Each group will present their projects in the last meeting, followed by a self-reflection session. A group report is also required to submit by the end of the course.

courses.subject: GENA
courses.title: Service Learning - Integrating and Applying STEAM Skills in the Community
courses.description:
To support the development of Hong Kong as an international innovation and technology hub, and foster new growth drivers and new strengths, the Chief Executive has announced in the 2022 Policy Address to step up the promotion of STEAM education in primary and secondary schools. It is important to better equip our students with 21st century competencies, unleash their potentials and nurture future I&T talents for Hong Kong, thereby enhancing Hong Kong’s international competitiveness.

“Service Learning – Integrating and Applying STEAM Skills in the Community” encourages students to illustrate and teach STEAM concepts and theories to secondary students. Motivating students to supervise and join their secondary students to promote and practise STEAM concepts with primary students through organizing workshop, project learning, thematic learning, as well as designs and inventions. The STEAM concepts include basic principles and concepts in science, programming, AI, etc. The course also aims to integrate service and learning experiences through community service activities. It seeks to cultivate students’ leadership skills, and to foster their self-awareness and empathy towards others and the community at large. In addition, the programme also emphasizes reflection on the quality of leadership that demonstrates while providing service, with the particular focus on intrapersonal and interpersonal competencies.

SDG goals “Quality Education” and “Partnerships for the Goals” will be achieved to strive for a better and more sustainable future for all. The course seeks to provide quality education to the primary and secondary school students by offering learning tools to develop their potential in order to grow into productive adults. It also encourages effective partnerships between University, secondary, and primary school students and nurtures their experience on collaboration and management of resources.

The course instructor is expected to conduct at least one session of on-site supervision for each group in order to assess students’ performance and commitment while peer-evaluation is also implemented.

courses.title: The Characteristics of Western Culture
courses.description:
This course will introduce students to some of the themes and characteristics of western culture, such as: aspects on religion, philosophy, politics and society.

courses.description:
This course begins with a brief but comprehensive exploration of pre-20th century American history, and then quickly moves on to the most important events and issues of the last 100 years of American history and culture. In addition to covering historical events and persons, focus is placed on reoccurring American themes, such as individual freedom and social equality. For students who wish to practice English and gain a greater understanding of the contemporary United States.

Advisory: For Year 2 or above College students only.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For NA students. Not for History Majors. Pre-requisite: GENA1112/GEJC1120 and GENA1113
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end the course, students will be able to:

1) discuss significant social, historical, political and cultural events from throughout American history.

2) explain how modern American life is influenced by its history.

3) appraise current issues in America with opinions supported by historical research.

4) present and argue a position using historical research to support their.

courses.subject: GENA
courses.title: Appreciation of Art
courses.description:
This course aims at introducing important works of art in the Chinese and Western traditions to students and helping them to develop their ability to appreciate art. Art works, including paintings and sculptures, will be discussed.

Advisory: For Year 2 or above College students only.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For NA students. Not for Fine Arts Majors and students who have taken GENA2262 or 2272. Pre-requisite: GENA1112/GEJC1120 and GENA1113
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end the course, students will be able to:
1) manage specific terminologies and analytical methods of visual arts.
2) describe a general view on the development of tradition of Chinese and Western Arts.
3) identify representative masterpieces in these two traditions.
4) appreciate and evaluate a piece of art work, and be able to analyze it systemically in writing.
courses.course_syllabus:
藝術是人類文明文化的結晶。不同時期不同傳統的藝術作品，以不同方式，呈現人類的精神生活。本科旨在引導同學欣賞中西藝術作品，尤其著重將藝術品置放於其產生的歷史文化脈絡，分析它們如何透過不同的形式和內容，展現藝術家對自身與時代的關懷。
傳統西方藝術主要包括繪畫、雕塑、版畫和建築；中國則以書法和繪畫為藝術之首。本科將分兩部份：第一部份探討中國藝術，介紹由十世紀宋代至二十世紀的繪畫。第二部份則討論西方藝術，並集中介紹十四世紀文藝復興至二十世紀西方具代表性的繪畫和雕塑。透過分析和比較中西藝術作品，本科希望同學能欣賞到中西藝術之美，認識兩個藝術傳統的特質和相異之處，從而培養同學的藝術品味和修養。
專題包括：
中國： 早期中國繪畫
宋代繪畫 (10－13世紀)
元代繪畫 (13世紀末－14世紀)
明代繪畫 (14世紀末－17世紀初)
清代繪畫 (17－20世紀初)
西方： 文藝復興 I (15－16世紀)
文藝復興II (15－16世紀)
巴洛克 I (17世紀)
巴洛克 II與洛可可 (17世紀－18世紀中)
新古典主義與浪漫主義 (18世紀末－19世紀初)
現代西方藝術潮流 (19－20世紀)
courses.feedback_evaluation: Teacher should provide a clear teaching plan before the course commences. Another evaluation exercise will be held at end of the course. An on line discussion platform may be installed if appropriate.

courses.subject: GENA
courses.title: Women, Men and Culture
courses.description:
This course takes an anthropological perspective to address gender and sexuality. Anthropologists argue that sex, gender, and the relationship between men and women are not given but largely products of cultural and social processes. We argue that political, economic, material, and environmental factors are a part of such processes. This course will start with introducing core concerns, arguments, and approaches related to gender and sexuality. After the introductory sessions, we will focus, week by week, on common (or controversial) gender and sexual issues we encounter in lives. These weeks will be discussion intensive and relevant analysis and scholarly works will be introduced to deepen your understanding of gender and sexuality via the topics. Students are encouraged to examine their own gender identities and beliefs critically; to not only understand how our gender assumptions are shaped but also to develop their own gender statement.

Advisory: For Year 2 or above College students only.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For NA students. Not for Anthropology Majors and students who have taken ANTH2310/UGEC2653. Pre-requisite: GENA1112/GEJC1120 and GENA1113.
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end the course, students will be able to:

1) acquire a holistic understanding of the making of gender and sexuality.

2) analyze contemporary gender issues anthropologically.

3) develop their own gender and sexual statement.

4) apply idea learned to their lives and have alternative choices to cope with related challenges.

courses.subject: GENA
courses.title: Debates in Human Values
courses.description:
This course explores key areas of conflict in human values, such as nationalism, religion, preservation, gender, money, violence, and media, and considers questions such as "Why love your country?". "Why believe in religion?", "Why preserve the environment?" and "Is war ever justified?" These questions have no clear answers, but the questions themselves are essential in considering how human beings should live: the course is designed to make students think about their values.

Advisory: For Year 2 or above College students only.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For NA students. Not for Anthropology Majors. Pre-requisite: GENA1112/GEJC1120 and GENA1113.
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end the course, students will be able to:

1) identify the wide variety of influences on human values.

2) understand the relationship of individuals with the society regarding values.

3) re-examine their own values and the way to live with others whose own values are very different.

courses.subject: GENA
courses.title: Founders' Ideals and New Asia Spirit
courses.description:
This course is aimed at inquiry into the ideal and goals, history and spirit of New Asia College, as well as some related thoughts of the founders. The College was founded with severe financial difficulties. The ideals of the College were shaped in a period of difficulty and hardship, but those ideals and the New Asia spirit remain relevant during our more affluent era. Our founders had set the goals for the College to preserve and promote Chinese Culture, to strengthen humanistic education, and to enhance communication between East and West. To assist students to understand the ideal and spirit of the College, this course focuses on a few important issues related to being a Chinese in the present age and try to see what illuminative answers the founders had suggested. The course will be proceeded with lectures.

Advisory: For Year 2 or above College students only.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For NA students. Pre-requisite: GENA1112/GEJC1120 & GENA1113.
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end the course, students will be able to:

1) understand the founding history and the educational ideal of the New Asia College.

2) understand the meaning of “New Asia Spirit” with reference to the ideal of the College.

3) reflect on their standpoint in the historical context in order to set out the voyage of their life.

courses.subject: GENA
courses.title: Appreciation of Chinese Art
courses.description:
This course aims at enhancing students’ knowledge of Chinese culture through appreciation of Chinese art. Focusing on painting, calligraphy and various forms of decorative arts including jade and ceramics, it highlights the characteristics and development of Chinese art with an introduction of accomplished artists and masterpieces throughout the ages.

Advisory: For Year 2 or above College students only.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For NA students. Not for Fine Arts Majors and students who have taken GENA2152 or IASP2530. Pre-requisite: GENA1112/GEJC1120 and GENA1113.
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end the course, students will be able to:
1) manage general knowledge and appreciation methods of Chinese Arts
2) describe general development of Chinese Arts, and identify its masterpieces.
3) appreciate and evaluate an art piece, and analyze it systematically in writing.
courses.course_syllabus:
中國藝術豐富多彩，尤其是廣義的中國藝術，既有表現個人藝術造詣的傳統書法和繪畫，亦涵蓋許多材料質地不同、藝術性和實用性兼備的作品。本科將以專題形式，介紹不同材質的中國藝術傳統，探討它們所屬材質的特點、藝術特色與文化含義。透過分析代表性作品，本科希望引導同學欣賞中國藝術的特質，了解中國文化的底蘊，並提高同學的藝術修養。
探討媒介包括：陶器、玉器、青銅器、漆木、瓷器、金器、書畫、壁畫等。
courses.feedback_evaluation: Teacher should provide a clear teaching plan before the course commences. Another evaluation exercise will be held at end of the course. An on line discussion platform may be installed if appropriate.

courses.subject: GENA
courses.title: Appreciation of Western Art
courses.description:
This course aims at enhancing the students' knowledge of Western culture through the appreciation of Western art. Focusing mainly on painting, sculpture, architecture, mixed media, etc., it highlights the characteristics and development of Western art with an introduction of accomplished artists and masterpieces throughout the ages.

Advisory: For Year 2 or above College students only.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For NA students. Not for Fine Arts Majors and students who have taken GENA2152. Pre-requisite: GENA1112/GEJC1120 and GENA1113.
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end the course, students will be able to:
1) describe general knowledge and various period of development of Western Arts.
2) indicate interests and skills in appreciation of Western Arts.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. 視覺元素﹝一﹞
2. 視覺元素﹝二﹞
3. 文藝復興的藝術：人文精神的覺醒
4. 文藝復興的藝術：人文精神的覺醒
5. 參觀
6. 巴洛克的藝術：榮耀的激情

courses.subject: GENA
courses.title: American Themes Through Creative Expression

meetings.instructor:
Miss Aimee Catherine CHANG, 
Miss CHEN Cheryl

courses.description:
This course investigates American history, popular culture and social issues through the lens of creative medias including visual arts, music, short films, and literature. We will look at representations of American society with a critical eye—how has the meaning of these representations evolved from their historical context? Topics covered will include Indigenous Experience, Black American Experience, American Regionalism, Asian American Experience, Women’s Rights, The 2016 Election and LGBTQ Experience.

Advisory: For Year 2 or above College students only.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For NA students. Not for English Majors. Pre-requisite: GENA1112/GEJC1120 and GENA1113.
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end the course, students will be able to:
1) trace a progression of American History through the lens of cultural experience.
2) identify and analyze important works by influential American artists.
3) identify major trends in American culture.
4) explain the deeper meaning and finer nuances of the themes discussed.
5) explain how American life is influenced by the themes discussed.
6) arrange discussion and written response on a sub-topic of a major course theme.
courses.course_syllabus:
Due to course’s focus on contemporary issues, please note that content is subject to change in the case that significant social/cultural events take place in the US prior to the start of the semester.

Introduction: What Is America?
The American Family

Racial and Ethnic Minorities

courses.subject: GENA
courses.title: General History of China
courses.description:
This course is aimed at introducing the main course of changes in Chinese history and the value of Chinese cultural heritage. Through lectures and discussions, it covers major issues in development of Chinese history. Examples of the topics include the origin of Chinese culture, milestones in dynastic history, intellectual thoughts and social structures. After taking this course, students are expected to develop critical thinking and analysis skills in a historical context, and further interests in the learning of Chinese culture.

Advisory: For Year 2 or above College students only.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For NA students. Not for History Majors and students who have taken UGEA2230. Pre-requisite: GENA1112/GEJC1120 and GENA1113.
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end the course, students will be able to:

1. acquire a general knowledge and understanding in Chinese history.

2. appreciate how the humanistic values and societal structures evolve and develop from traditional to modern China.

3. criticize and evaluate issues in contemporary Chinese communities in a historic context.

4. develop further interests in the study of Chinese culture.

courses.subject: GENA
courses.title: Peoples and Cultures of Southeast Asia
courses.description:
(GENA2332 is double-coded with ANTH2450.)

The primary aim of this course is to introduce the peoples and cultures of Southeast Asia through anthropological studies. The course will highlight cultural similarities and differences, and explore the issues of ethnicity, development and national identity.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For NA students. Not for Anthropology Majors and students who have taken ANTH2450. Pre-requisite: GENA1112/GEJC1120 and GENA1113
courses.learning_outcomes:
Students will be acquainted with the prehistory, history, geography and the forces of colonialism and post-colonialism in Southeast Asia, all of which will help them understand the current situation in the region.

Students will be made to reflect on how social, cultural and political institutions provide lenses for understanding Southeast Asian society.

Students will be introduced to current crises confronting the region such as ecological/environmental disasters and religio-political conflicts including terrorism, which have implications for the world at large.

Upon completing the course, students will be able to use the analytical tools they have acquired to understand their own societies. In this sense, the course fulfils the anthropological condition of studying the other in order to better understand the self.
courses.course_syllabus:
The course aims to provide the students with an anthropological understanding of Southeast Asia, a region of the world famed for its numerous cultures, languages, religions and civilizations.

Part One of the course will focus on the prehistory, archeology and peopling of the region. Students will be introduced to the origins of agriculture, the development of complex state societies and the influence of world religions on the region.

Part Two will focus on more contemporary history by looking at the complex interactions between traditional cultural systems and modernizing forces such as European colonialism in Southeast Asia. One aspect we will examine is how European

colonialism influenced modern nation-building processes in countries like Singapore, Malaysia, Thailand and Myanmar/Burma. In this respect, we will focus on how traditional features of social organization such as ethnicity, religion, politics and economics have been transformed and deployed to govern the modern states of Southeast Asia.

Part Three of the course will examine social institutions such as gender and sexuality and foodways in Southeast Asian societies as well as the various challenges that modern day Southeast Asia faces, including environmental degradations, climatic catastrophes such as the Indian Ocean tsunami of 2004 as well as the recent Cyclone Nargis that hit Myanmar in May 2008, and ethnic/religious conflicts and human rights concerns in the region.

Participation: 15%

Map Quiz: 15%

Term Paper: 30%

Final Test: 40%

Most updated syllabus and assessment will be announced in class.

courses.subject: GENA
courses.title: The Appreciation of Music Cultures

meetings.location: Lee Shau Kee Archi Bldg G04

courses.description:
This course introduces basic concepts, genres and aesthetics of both Chinese and Western music to students. Efforts have been made to cover both popular and art repertoires from Western and Chinese music. No previous music training is required, however, a general understanding of both two music cultures are expected by the end of the course.

Advisory: For Year 2 or above College students only.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For NA students. Not for Music Majors and students who have taken UGED2080. Pre-requisite: GENA1112/GEJC1120 and GENA1113.
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end the course, students will be able to:
1. acquire basic knowledge in significant music genres, performance practices and musical conventions from Chinese and Western societies.
2. understand and appreciate both Chinese and Western cultural heritages and music traditions.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Introduction: basic concept, terminology, instruments…
2. Notation in Chinese and Western music

7. Catalogue arias--- tradition of parti buffe (count places, numbers, instruments, names)---許冠傑、鄭君綿…
8. Western music in China---Chinese music in the West
9. Parody: parody mass Missa L’homme armé , Three quotations from Don Giovanni---草原小姐妹、白毛女…
10. Chinese music in movies
- 笑傲江湖、秦俑、霸王別姬…

 - Copying Beethoven (Beethoven)
 - Immortal Beloved (Beethoven)

courses.subject: GENA
courses.title: Service Learning Project
courses.description:
This course aims to cultivate among students a caring attitude for the society. Grounded on the principles of service-learning, altruism, volunteerism and experiential learning, this course assists students in the integration of their service-learning experiences in order to develop an attitude of care and concern towards under-privileged groups. Students are also engaged in in-depth reflection on the relationship between individuals and the society. Through lectures, service-learning experience, self-reflection and group discussion, students are required to apply theories and concepts to design and implement a series of service for a chosen disadvantaged group affiliated with a non-governmental organization. After the service, students have to undertake presentation and discussion to consolidate the experience in personal, teamwork and the society level.

Advisory: For Year 2 or above College students only.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
For NA students who have taken GENA1112/GEJC1120 & GENA1113.
Not for students who have taken GENA1114, 1115, 1116 or 1117.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Concepts of service learning
- Service learning as a philosophy
- Service learning as a pedagogy

2. Individuals and the society
- Concepts of altruism
- Concepts of volunteerism

3. Understanding the needy group in the community
- Needs assessment strategy and techniques

4. Service Techniques
- Program planning and evaluation
- Teamwork

5. Principles of Experiential and Reflective Learning
- Experiential learning cycle
- Reflective learning

Remark: Four lectures of 2 hours each will be provided on the concepts of service learning, volunteerism and altruism, needs assessment and program planning. Students in small teams are required to plan and conduct a minimum of six sessions of services for the designated group in need. Four sessions of 2 hours each of presentations cum discussion are followed.

courses.subject: GENA
courses.title: Intangible Heritage in Hong Kong
courses.description:
(GENA2362 is double-coded with ANTH2370.)

Hong Kong, with its dominant image as an Asian global city as well as gateway to mainland China, has been representing itself with an image of East meets West for its tourist attractions in the last century. In order to maintain this image for its world visitors, there is no doubt that Hong Kong needs to find a balance between its global metropolitan aspect and unique cultural heritage with local characteristics in many ways. Yet, before moving on for extensive intangible heritage preservation, we might want to think about: What kind of heritage do we want to pass down to the coming generations? What kind of long-term policy do we have? How should the intangible heritage preservation and management be carried out? In this course, different types of intangible heritage in Hong Kong will be introduced and explained, and students will be guided to discuss and rethink the use and meanings of heritage from a socio-cultural anthropological perspectives.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For NA students. Not for Anthropology Majors and students who have taken ANTH2370. Pre-requisite: GENA1112/GEJC1120 and GENA1113
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Students will have learnt about major anthropological theories and various intangible heritage in Hong Kong as well as relevant current situation, including changes in the urban and rural areas, and be able to critically identify factors affecting socio-cultural changes and political development in the society.

2. Students will be able to examine changing cultural values in Hong Kong and become more conscious of aspects of culture that they take for granted, .

3. Students will have learnt about different local lifestyles and their interaction with the changing living environment, and to develop an understanding of the role of tradition and globalization.

4. After the course, students will be able to appreciate the diversity of cultural heritage in Hong Kong and the processes that mold and shape cultural identity.

5. Students will have learnt skills in research design, cultural data collection, communication, and presentation of results.

courses.subject: GENA
courses.title: Art Institutions in Twentieth-Century China
courses.description:
(GENA2372 is double-coded with CUMT2013.)

The course examines the correlation between art and institutions in twentieth-century China, aiming to encourage students to think about modern Chinese art through the concept of the artworld. The downfall of the Qing dynasty and the establishment of the Republican China transformed the social and institutional organisation of the production, distribution, and consumption of art as well as the traditional patronage system in modern China. The structural changes conditioned the emergence of formal and informal art institutions that facilitated yet constrained artistic practices, laying the foundation for the development of a modern art world in China. The course looks at the history of modern Chinese art and the formation of different art institutions in the sociocultural and economic context of modern China. Weekly topics are structured chronologically and thematically, which cover a wide range of themes, including art schools, art societies, museums, exhibitions, and art market. Adopting an interdisciplinary approach, the course offers students multi-perspectives to understand the transformation of modern Chinese art and the interactions between artistic practices and society in modern China.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
1. Not for Cultural Management (CUMS and CUMT); and Public Humanities Majors
2. Not for students who have taken CUMT2013
3. For students of New Asia College
4. Pre-requisites: GENA1112/GEJC1120 and GENA1113
courses.learning_outcomes:
• Explain the theory of the artworld and history of art institutions in modern China
• Identify and describe the historical background, aesthetics, and social factors reflected in specific artworks.
• Identify and interpret the correlation between artistic styles and the institutional organisation.
• Reflect upon the roles of art institutions in the process of art creation, production, distribution and consumption.
• Select research materials and develop original research topics on modern Chinese art
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Introduction: The Theory of the Artworld and the Emergence of a Modern Art World in China
Howard Becker, “Art Worlds and Collective Activity”, in Art Worlds 25th Ed. (Berkeley: University of California Press, 2008), 1-39.
Roberta Wue, “Introduction”, Art Worlds: Artists, Images, and Audiences in Late Nineteenth-Century Shanghai (Hong Kong: Hong Kong University Press, 2014), 1-21.

2. The Interaction between art creation and dynamic urban culture in major Chinese cities
Jonathan Hay, “Painting and the Built Environment in Late Nineteenth-Century Shanghai”, Maxwell Hearn ed., Chinese Art Modern Expressions (New York: Metropolitan Museum of Art, 2001), 61-101.
Wen-hsin Yeh, “The Shanghai Gaze: Visual Culture and Images of Modernity”, Jason Kuo ed., Visual Culture in Shanghai 1850s-1930s (Washington: New Academia Publishing, 2007), 333-45.

3. How was art taught through the newly established educational system and curriculum?
Mayching Kao, “Reforms in Education and the Beginning of the Western-Style Painting Movement in China”, in Julia Andrews and Kuiyi Shen ed., A Century in Crisis: Modernity and Tradition in the Art of Twentieth-Century China (New York: Guggenheim Museum, 1998), 146-171.
Jane Zheng, “Private Tutorial Art Schools in the Shanghai Market Economy: The Shanghai Art School, 1913-1919”, Modern China 35, 3 (2009): 313-343.

4. Artistic network: art societies and their functions
Zheng Shengtian, “Waves Lashed the Bund from the West Shanghai’s Art Scene in the 1930s”, in Jo-Anne Birnie Danzker, Ken Lum and Zheng Shengtian eds., Shanghai Modern, 1919-1945 (Munich: Museum Villa Stuck, 2004), 174-99.
Julia Andrews and Kuiyi Shen, “Traditionalism as a Modern Stance: The Chinese Women’s Calligraphy and Painting Society”, Modern Chinese Literature and Culture 11, no. 1 (1999): 1-30.

5. Publishing culture: a new way to disseminate artworks and generate public discourse
Waara, Carrie, “Invention, Industry, Art: The Commercialisation of Culture in Republican Art Magazines.” In Sherman Cochrane ed., Inventing Nanjing Road: Commercial Culture in Shanghai, 1900-1945 (Ithaca, NY: East Asian Program, Cornell University, 1999), 61-89
Richard Vinograd, “Patrimonies in Press: Art Publishing, Cultural Politics, and Canon Construction in the Career of Di Baoxian”, in Joshua Fogel ed., The Role of Japan in Modern Chinese Art (Berkeley: University of California Press, 2012), 245-272.

6. New technology: the introduction of photography and its impact on art
Liu Yu-Jen, “Second Only to the Original: Rhetoric and Practice in the Photographic Reproduction of Art in Early Twentieth-Century China”, Art History 37, 1 (February 2014): 68-95.
Gu Yi, “What’s in a Name? Photography and the Reinvention of Visual Truth in China, 1840-1911”, The Art Bulletin XCV, 1 (March 2013):120-38.

7. How did museum change the perception and presentation of art?
Christopher Whitehead, “Establishing the Manifesto: Art Histories in the Nineteenth-century Museum”, Simon Knell, Suzanne MacLeod and Sheila Watson eds., Museum Revolutions: How Museums Change and are Changed (London: Routledge, 2007), 48-60.
Lisa Claypool, “Zhang Jian and China’s First Museum”, Journal of Asian Studies 64, no. 3 (August, 2005): 567-604.

8. Constructing the national identity through international exhibitions
Michaela Pejcochova, “The First Exhibitions and the Origins of Collecting Modern Chinese Art in Europe”, Bulletin of the National Gallery in Prague, XXVII (2017): 6-22.
Eric Lefebvre, “Ways to Modernity: Chinese Artists in Paris”, in Paris. Chinese Painting: Legacy of the 20th Century Chinese Masters (Hong Kong: Hong Kong Museum of Art, 2014), 24-37.

10. Collecting activities and the formation of collections of modern Chinese art
Jean Baudrillard, “The System of Collecting”, John Elsner and Roger Cardinal eds., The Cultures of Collecting (London: Reaktion Books, 1994), 7-24.
Zaixin Hong, “Florence Ayscough: pioneer promoter of modern Chinese painting in America”, Jason Steuber and Guolong Lai eds., Collectors, Collections & Collecting the Arts of China (Florida: University Press of Florida, 2014), 119-50.

11. Art and its audience: the consumption and reception of art
Shih Shou-chien 石守謙, “Huihua guanzhong yu guonan: ershi shiji qianqi Zhongguo huajia de yasu jueze 繪畫、觀眾與國難：二十世紀前期中國畫家的雅俗抉擇 [Painting, Audience and National Crisis: A Choice between Elegance and Vulgarity of Chinese Artists in the Early Twentieth Century].” Meishushi yanjiu jikan 美術史研究集刊 [Journal of the Study of Art History] 21 (2006): 151-88.
Craig Clunas, “The Nation”, in Chinese Painting and Its Audiences (Princeton: Princeton University Press, 2017), 155-191.

12. Art market: professional intermediaries and a new patronage system
Kuiyi Shen, “Patronage and the Beginning of a Modern Art World in Late Qing Shanghai,” in Jason Kuo ed., In Visual Culture in Shanghai 1850s-1930s (Washington D. C.: New Academia Pub., 2007), 13-27.
Pedith Chan, “The Business of Art: The Art Market”, in The Making of A Modern Art World: Institutionalisation and Legitimisation of Guohua in Republican Shanghai (Leiden: Brill, 2017), 186-259.

13. The structure of the Chinese artworld since the Mao era and Wrap Up
Julia Andrews and Kuiyi Shen, “Art after Mao, 1976-1989”, in The Art of Modern China (Berkeley: University of California Press, 2012), 201-223.
Svetlana Kharchenkova, Nataliya Komarova, and Olav Velthuis, “Official Art Organizations in the Emerging Markets of China and Russia”, in Olav Velthuis and Stefano Baia Curioni eds., Cosmopolitan Canvases: Globalization of Markets for Contemporary Art (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 2015), 78-101.

2. The Interaction between art creation and dynamic urban culture in major Chinese cities
Jonathan Hay, “Painting and the Built Environment in Late Nineteenth-Century Shanghai”, Maxwell Hearn ed., Chinese Art Modern Expressions (New York: Metropolitan Museum of Art, 2001), 61-101.

3. How was art taught through the newly established educational system and curriculum?
Mayching Kao, “Reforms in Education and the Beginning of the Western-Style Painting Movement in China”, in Julia Andrews and Kuiyi Shen ed., A Century in Crisis: Modernity and Tradition in the Art of Twentieth-Century China (New York: Guggenheim Museum, 1998), 146-171.
Jane Zheng, “Private Tutorial Art Schools in the Shanghai Market Economy: The Shanghai Art School, 1913-1919”, Modern China 35, 3 (2009): 313-343.

4. Artistic network: art societies and their functions
Zheng Shengtian, “Waves Lashed the Bund from the West Shanghai’s Art Scene in the 1930s”, in Jo-Anne Birnie Danzker, Ken Lum and Zheng Shengtian eds., Shanghai Modern, 1919-1945 (Munich: Museum Villa Stuck, 2004), 174-99.
Julia Andrews and Kuiyi Shen, “Traditionalism as a Modern Stance: The Chinese Women’s Calligraphy and Painting Society”, Modern Chinese Literature and Culture 11, no. 1 (1999): 1-30.

5. Publishing culture: a new way to disseminate artworks and generate public discourse
Waara, Carrie, “Invention, Industry, Art: The Commercialisation of Culture in Republican Art Magazines.” In Sherman Cochrane ed., Inventing Nanjing Road: Commercial Culture in Shanghai, 1900-1945 (Ithaca, NY: East Asian Program, Cornell University, 1999), 61-89
Richard Vinograd, “Patrimonies in Press: Art Publishing, Cultural Politics, and Canon Construction in the Career of Di Baoxian”, in Joshua Fogel ed., The Role of Japan in Modern Chinese Art (Berkeley: University of California Press, 2012), 245-272.

6. New technology: the introduction of photography and its impact on art
Liu Yu-Jen, “Second Only to the Original: Rhetoric and Practice in the Photographic Reproduction of Art in Early Twentieth-Century China”, Art History 37, 1 (February 2014): 68-95.
Gu Yi, “What’s in a Name? Photography and the Reinvention of Visual Truth in China, 1840-1911”, The Art Bulletin XCV, 1 (March 2013):120-38.

7. How did museum change the perception and presentation of art?
Christopher Whitehead, “Establishing the Manifesto: Art Histories in the Nineteenth-century Museum”, Simon Knell, Suzanne MacLeod and Sheila Watson eds., Museum Revolutions: How Museums Change and are Changed (London: Routledge, 2007), 48-60.
Lisa Claypool, “Zhang Jian and China’s First Museum”, Journal of Asian Studies 64, no. 3 (August, 2005): 567-604.

8. Constructing the national identity through international exhibitions
Michaela Pejcochova, “The First Exhibitions and the Origins of Collecting Modern Chinese Art in Europe”, Bulletin of the National Gallery in Prague, XXVII (2017): 6-22.
Eric Lefebvre, “Ways to Modernity: Chinese Artists in Paris”, in Paris. Chinese Painting: Legacy of the 20th Century Chinese Masters (Hong Kong: Hong Kong Museum of Art, 2014), 24-37.

10. Collecting activities and the formation of collections of modern Chinese art
Jean Baudrillard, “The System of Collecting”, John Elsner and Roger Cardinal eds., The Cultures of Collecting (London: Reaktion Books, 1994), 7-24.
Zaixin Hong, “Florence Ayscough: pioneer promoter of modern Chinese painting in America”, Jason Steuber and Guolong Lai eds., Collectors, Collections & Collecting the Arts of China (Florida: University Press of Florida, 2014), 119-50.

11. Art and its audience: the consumption and reception of art
Shih Shou-chien 石守謙, “Huihua guanzhong yu guonan: ershi shiji qianqi Zhongguo huajia de yasu jueze 繪畫、觀眾與國難：二十世紀前期中國畫家的雅俗抉擇 [Painting, Audience and National Crisis: A Choice between Elegance and Vulgarity of Chinese Artists in the Early Twentieth Century].” Meishushi yanjiu jikan 美術史研究集刊 [Journal of the Study of Art History] 21 (2006): 151-88.
Craig Clunas, “The Nation”, in Chinese Painting and Its Audiences (Princeton: Princeton University Press, 2017), 155-191.

12. Art market: professional intermediaries and a new patronage system
Kuiyi Shen, “Patronage and the Beginning of a Modern Art World in Late Qing Shanghai,” in Jason Kuo ed., In Visual Culture in Shanghai 1850s-1930s (Washington D. C.: New Academia Pub., 2007), 13-27.
Pedith Chan, “The Business of Art: The Art Market”, in The Making of A Modern Art World: Institutionalisation and Legitimisation of Guohua in Republican Shanghai (Leiden: Brill, 2017), 186-259.

13. The structure of the Chinese artworld since the Mao era and Wrap Up
Julia Andrews and Kuiyi Shen, “Art after Mao, 1976-1989”, in The Art of Modern China (Berkeley: University of California Press, 2012), 201-223.
Svetlana Kharchenkova, Nataliya Komarova, and Olav Velthuis, “Official Art Organizations in the Emerging Markets of China and Russia”, in Olav Velthuis and Stefano Baia Curioni eds., Cosmopolitan Canvases: Globalization of Markets for Contemporary Art (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 2015), 78-101.

courses.subject: GENA
courses.title: Empowerment through Nonviolent Communication: Theory and Practice
courses.description:
From the first word you spoke as a child to the last word you ever say, the language you use to communicate is shaping how you experience your life, including your sense of self, conflicts with others, success in your career, and relationships with those you love. But what forms of interpersonal communication create pain, alienation, and amplify conflicts? And what forms of communication overcome fear, create trust, freedom, and fulfilling human connection? “Empowerment through Nonviolent Communication” provides students with a proven toolset for managing interpersonal conflicts, called Nonviolent Communication (NVC), while preserving trust and connection. These tools can be used in nearly all areas of social life. NVC, also known as Compassionate Communication, was pioneered by clinical psychologist Marshall B. Rosenberg and further developed by decades of global practitioners. Upon completing the course, students will understand NVC theories and be able to use its various tools in their daily lives. Lectures and discussions will also address the use of NVC in the context of Hong Kong and Chinese culture more generally.

Students are advised that NVC methods cannot be learned as a purely intellectual exercise: you must bring to class your heart and mind. Learning activities will involve personal sharing, role plays, and reflective journal writing. Within respectful limits, students must be willing to engage in personal self-reflection and sharing; also, students must strictly abide by a confidentiality agreement not to disclose the personal stories of others outside of class.

This course supports advancement towards the Sustainable Development Goals of Quality Education, Reducing Inequality, and Peace, Justice and Strong Institutions. Equitable participation in society and education are advanced through communication without coercion and harm, which is nonviolent communication. Institutions are strengthened through nonviolent communication that promotes reform and advancement while affirming the human need for security and respect.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
1. For NA students
2. Pre-requisite: GENA1112/GEJC1120 and GENA1113
courses.course_attributes:
SDG-GE #5 Gender Equality
SDG-GE #10 Reducing Inequality
SDG-GE #16 Peace, Justice and Strong Institutions
Experiential Learning Course
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Understand and apply key concepts and theory of Nonviolent Communication.
2. Develop the skills to (1) identify and communicate one’s own feelings and needs and (2) listen to others with empathy and sustained attention.
3. Based on knowledge from the course, critically analyse and make evaluative arguments about violence and nonviolence in real life situations.
4. Create and carry out plans to use NVC in daily life.
5. Gain an introductory understanding of the wider modern discource of nonviolence, from which NVC emerged.
6. Understand the relationship between nonviolence and other social forces, such as gender inequality, political events, and Chinese cultural traditions. (This goal contributes to SDG#10, Reducing Inequality and SDG#16, Peace, Justice and Strong Institutions).
courses.course_syllabus:
* *Week 1: Introduction**

Course goals, format, and expectations. Introduction to themes and self-introduction of class participants.

* *NVC Theory and Practice (Core Content)**

* *Week 2: Giving and Disconnecting Language**

Lecture and activity focusing on how everyday language frequently used harms, or the threat of harm to control or motivate others. Student will identify their own experiences of giving and of disconnecting language.

* *Week 3: Separating Observations from Judgments**

Lecture and activity focusing on the skill of making and communicating nonjudgmental observations.

* *Week 4: Feelings and Needs**

Lecture and activity focusing on understanding, identifying and communicating feelings and needs, within NVC theory; the interrelation between needs, feelings and judgements; and agency relative to feelings.

* *Week 5: Requests and Demands**

Lecture and activity focusing on the importance of communicating about needs; the difference between requests and demands; and what to do when interpersonal conflicts about needs cannot be resolved to mutual satisfaction.

* *Week 6: Listening**

Lecture and activity focusing on the theory and practice of empathic listening.

* *Week 7: Mourning, Celebrating, and Expressing Anger**

Lecture and activity focusing on accepting failures, disappointments, and pain; affirming and recognizing achievements and good fortune; and expressing anger authentically, but constructively.

* *NVC in Society (Topics, selected by instructor)**

* *Week 8: Social Science Research on NVC**

What is the state of evidence-based research into NVC? How is NVC being used in contemporary professional disciplines (e.g., nursing, criminology)?

* *Week 9: NVC and Gender and Sexuality**

Lecture and activity focusing on the implications of NVC for the gendered ways that boys and girls, and later men and women, are socialized to experience and manage emotions and needs; NVC as it pertains to sexual minorities will also be considered.

* *Week 10: “Nonviolence” as Modern Moral Ideal**

Nonviolence” as a positive modern ethic of action emerged in the 20th century. Readings and class materials will introduce classic statements on nonviolence, such as by M. Gandhi and Martin Luther King.

* *Week 11: Nonviolent Action versus Nonviolent Communication**

Lecture and activity will introduce students to the basic differences and similarities between “nonviolent action” (NVA) and “nonviolent communication” (NVC). NVA is the form of social movement protest action pioneered by Mahatma Gandhi, called Satyagraha, and later diffused globally as NVA.

* *Week 12 & 13: NVC in Chinese Society**

Students will examine the question of in what ways traditional Chinese values and contemporary Chinese social institutions can be resources to support and/or conflict with the values and practices of NVC.

courses.subject: GENA
courses.title: Media and Everyday Life
courses.description:
(GENA3070 is double-coded with COMM1110.)

Modern media are everywhere; they mediate nearly all aspects of everyday life. Media forms old and new – newspapers, magazines, films, radio, television, pop music, Internet, social media, and mobile phones – are shaping our social and political life, cultivating our cultural imaginations, and articulating our personal experiences and a sense of belonging in a rapidly changing world. This course examines the many roles of the media in the web of modern life.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For NA students. Not for Journalism and Communication Majors and Global Communication Majors; and students who have taken COMM1110. Pre-requisite: GENA1112/GEJC1120 and GENA1113
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of the course, students should:

1. Be equipped with enhanced media literacy.

2. Be able to understand the “operational logic” of different mass media and be able t to recognize the key issues related to media production.

3. Be able to apply theoretical concepts to analyze various media phenomena, especially towards the local mass media.

4. Students are able to understand the role mass media played in a post-modern society and to develop critical and analytical capabilities to evaluate and consume the media products.
courses.course_syllabus:
(For reference only, subject to changes)

1. Introduction: How do we visualize our society and ourselves through the media?

2. Images, gender roles and post-modern identities

3. Advertising – the lifeblood of contemporary media system

4. What is News?

5. Infotainment magazines and consumerism

6. Amusing ourselves to death – the impact of TV entertainment culture

7. Popular music and the celebrity culture

8. New media technology and broadcasting ourselves

9 Media Effects: Sex & Violence

10. Media Effects: Other effects

11. Mass media and political economy

12. The Audience’s choice

13. Conclusion: three types of theoretical approaches
